content.description:
Probably the best full length route at Ceder

P#1 follow the corner to a tree then go right and continue up past a crack to a large bowl to belay

P#2 continue up a water groove to a two bolt belay

P#3 (crux) climb a black water grove with balance moves past a bolt and the up through a smaller groove to another two bolt belay

P#4 climb up and over the bulge to another two bolt anchor

Decent- rappel the route
content.location: Far left on the tallest section of wall is a large left facing and slightly overhanging dihedral. Start here on the slab

content.description:
Water groove is smooth and about a hand and a fist sized crack. Bring a couple of #2s and #3s for this. There is a bolt or 2 along the way on the second pitch.

Pitch 1: 40 feet- Gain the large bulge from the forest floor. Can solo, it's 5.4 slab, top of bulge is a good stage for the second pitch.

Pitch 2: 70 Feet - Work the groove. Once it becomes high angle and there are some bolts on the face and eyebrows to plug for protection.
content.protection: Larger cams for the groove, a few bolts to protect. There are 3 bolts in a line for the anchors of the second pitch, but no chains or rap rings. If you find biners, don't booty them, they are not bail pieces.
content.location: Water groove to the left of Angry Nomad.

content.description: Starts the same as Groove Licker and Pole Envy. 1st pitch is 5th class with occasional gear. We only did the second. Start from the bolted anchor and traverse right into the deep groove. A black tricam protects the first eyebrow. Continue up and there is a bomber WC 11 nut in the groove. Pass marginal gear (maybe a #2 or a #3, hexes would be great here) and the crack get steeper. Find what gear you can and/or run it on easy ground to the top. Bomber mid to large cams at the top ease your mind as you trend slightly right to the chain anchor.
content.protection: Standard single rack of cams, doubles in  BD#2 and #3, hexes would be a good idea but not necessary.
content.location: If you can find the large groove routes to the right (Jehovas Wetness and Angry Nomad) these are the shallower grooves just to the left. On the Art Loeb, continue up the steep section until the trail is basically at the cliff and there will be a small trail.

content.description:
Easy climbing off the belay. Go straight into the very shallow groove and set a brown or blue tri-cam into the weird pod. Can also get a decent cam above this in an eyebrow (#2 yellow TCU maybe?). Continue slabbing up finding occasional finger sized pieces until you get to the first high bolt. Clip it and either continue straight up the face or trend left into the shallow groove. Marginal gear between the two bolts with an easy runout at the top.

We had a hard time finding the anchor, but when you get to the top trend hard right and there is a sketchy chain anchor equalizing two old bolts and a new bolt with a locker. Don't get suckered into one of the really old set of rap-less bolts.
content.protection: Metolius 00-6 (BD X4 .1 to 1) and tricams from black to blue, two bolts to a chain anchor
content.location: We stated up towards Gothic Groove and trended right. This put us at a random anchor in the face. We had to traverse right about 30-50ft to get to the start. The start is off an anchor with rapid links (the only anchor we found with links). You can also do the start of Pole Envy and traverse left.

climbs.name: Gothic Groove
climbs.fa: Brad Woolf, Sean Cobourn, John Saunders and Jeff Jenkins

content.description:
This route, like many other routes on the South Side, takes the easy 5.1 slab 300 feet to a large ledge. The third 5.8+ pitch is the real meat of the climb, and follows a gorgeous black water groove to the anchors.

While you are up on the ledge there are several other climbs of varying difficulty that start their crux pitches there as well.
content.protection:
Pitches 1+2: Whatever.

Pitch 3: A bit spicy. One bolt at 30 ft and a second at 50 ft protect the crux area. There also might be good gear in the flake in the first 10-15 ft, but it isn't of much use.
content.location:
You can see the water groove from the base, it makes a plumb line down to the upper ledge. Take whatever route to get up there.

To descend, there are bolted anchors to rap the climb in three raps. You will need double ropes or a tag line for the bottom two raps.

climbs.name: Glam Utopia
climbs.fa: Sean Coburn, Brad Woolf, Jeff Jenkins, John Saunders

content.description:
Directly to the right of Gothic Groove, this climb follows the same 5.1 slab up to the big ledge, then takes a bolt-protected line up a clean slab face.

This is a 5.10 in the guide, but it felt on par with Gothic Groove to the left and Kitty Klitter to the right so I think 5.9 would be more fitting.
content.protection:
Pitches 1+2: some cams and stuff, somewhat sparse protection but also very easy.

Pitch 3: Bolts.
content.location: Directly right of Gothic Groove. From the base, look for the straight water groove surrounded by a couple of bulgy corners. It is obvious once you get to the large ledge.

content.description:
Another route off the large ledge. Pretty fun climb.

Pitch 1+2: 300 feet of 5.1 slab.

Pitch 3: Slabby left-facing corner/groove.
content.protection:
Pitch 1+2: some trad gear, sparse. Bolted anchors.

Pitch 3: Mostly bolts. Climbing up to the first bolt you can get a .75 in the weird indentation left of the groove proper.
content.location: 20 feet right of Gothic Groove. From the base, look for a couple of bulges with corners bookending a big ledge. Once you get to the ledge it is obvious.

content.description:
Pitch 1: 5.2 100 ft

Pitch 2: 5.1 100 ft

Pitch 3: 5.6 105 ft. crux is 40 feet from the the anchors. Can be protected with two cams. You will need to build and belay stand at the top.

Pitch 4: 110 ft. Follow the water groove to the right from the top of the third pitch.

To repeal down from the top to the anchors on Pitch two you will need every bit of two seventy meter ropes.
content.protection: Trad. Anchors at the top of pitch 1, 2, and 4. Build one at top of pitch three.
content.location: There is a big arch at the bottom of the rock. Start Mexicant directly right of the arch.

content.description:
Pitch 1: 5.1 140 feet to anchors.

Pitch 2: 5.6 200 feet to anchors. There is one bolt right before the crux.

Pitch 3. 5.3 60 feet to anchors.
content.protection: Cams up to a size 4. one bolt right before the crux.
content.location: Follow the art loeb trail until the trail is very close to the rock and a small trial to the base of the rock. The route is the water groove on the right.

content.description: Ascend the face between Jehovah's Wetness and Angry Nomad.
content.protection: Couple of bolts supplemented by cams
content.location: Where Art Loeb Trail hits the cliffband, there are two obvious grooves.Â  This line goes between them.
